sentences: Early life ===
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Lauper was born in Brooklyn, New York City, to a Catholic family.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Her father, Fred, was of German and Swiss descent.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Her mother, Catrine (née Gallo), is of Italian descent (from Sicily).
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Lauper's siblings are younger brother Fred (nicknamed Butch), and older sister, Ellen.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Lauper's parents divorced when she was five.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Her mother remarried and divorced again.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Lauper grew up in the Ozone Park neighborhood of Queens and, as a child, listened to such artists as The Beatles and Judy Garland.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: At age 12, she began writing songs and playing an acoustic guitar given to her by her sister.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Lauper expressed herself with a variety of hair colors and eccentric clothing, and took a friend's advice to spell her name as "Cyndi" rather than "Cindy".
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Her unconventional sense of style led to classmates bullying and throwing stones at her.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Lauper went to Richmond Hill High School, but was expelled, although she later earned her GED.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: She left home at 17, to escape her abusive stepfather, intending to study art.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Her journey took her to Canada, where she spent two weeks in the woods with her dog Sparkle, trying to find herself.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: She eventually traveled to Vermont, where she took art classes at Johnson State College and supported herself working odd jobs.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: In 2019, Lauper gave the commencement address at Northern Vermont University - Johnson, the academic institution that now includes Johnson State.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: At this event, NVU awarded her the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: In the early 1970s, Lauper performed as a vocalist with various cover bands.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: One, called Doc West, covered disco songs as well as Janis Joplin.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: A later band, Flyer, was active in the New York metropolitan area, singing hits by bands including Bad Company, Jefferson Airplane and Led Zeppelin.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: Although Lauper was performing on stage, she was not happy singing covers.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: In 1977, Lauper damaged her vocal cords and took a year off from singing.
section: == Life and career == | === 1953–1979: Early life ===

sentences: She was told by doctors that she would never sing again, but regained her voice with the help of vocal coach Katie Agresta.

sentences: In 1978, Lauper met saxophone player John Turi through her manager Ted Rosenblatt.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Turi and Lauper formed a band named Blue Angel and recorded a demo tape of original music.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Steve Massarsky, manager of The Allman Brothers Band, heard the tape and liked Lauper's voice.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: He bought Blue Angel's contract for $5,000 and became their manager.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Lauper received recording offers as a solo artist, but held out, wanting the band to be included in any deal she made.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Blue Angel was eventually signed by Polydor Records and released a self-titled album on the label in 1980.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Lauper hated the album cover, saying that it made her look like Big Bird, but Rolling Stone magazine later included it as one of the 100 best new wave album covers (2003).
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Despite critical acclaim, the album sold poorly ("It went lead", as Lauper later joked) and the band broke up.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: The members of Blue Angel had a falling-out with Massarsky and fired him as their manager.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: He later filed an $80,000 suit against them, which forced Lauper into bankruptcy.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: After this Lauper temporarily lost her voice due to an inverted cyst in her vocal cord.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: After Blue Angel broke up, Lauper spent time, due to her financial problems, working in retail stores, waitressing at IHOP (which she quit after being demoted to hostess when the manager sexually harassed her), and singing in local clubs.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Her most frequent gigs were at El Sombrero.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: Music critics who saw Lauper perform with Blue Angel believed she had star potential due to her four-octave singing range.
section: == Life and career == | === 1980–1982: Blue Angel ===

sentences: In 1981, while singing in a local New York bar, Lauper met David Wolff, who took over as her manager and had her sign a recording contract with Portrait Records, a subsidiary of Epic Records.

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Lauper was in a relationship from 1982 to 1988 with her then manager, Dave Wolff.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Lauper has been married to actor David Thornton since 1991.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They have one son, Declyn Wallace Thornton Lauper  (born on November 19, 1997).
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Lauper has openly discussed her psoriasis, including in advertisements for Cosentyx.
section: == Personal life ==
== Activism ==

sentences: Activism ==
section: == Activism ==

sentences: Lauper has been an LGBT rights supporter throughout her career, campaigning for equality through various charities and gay pride events around the world.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: Lauper stated that she became involved in gay rights advocacy because her sister Ellen is a lesbian and because Lauper herself was passionate about equality.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: Lauper cites her sister Ellen as a role model.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: Her song "Above the Clouds" celebrates the memory of Matthew Shepard, a young gay man beaten to death in Wyoming.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: As a member of the Matthew Shepard Foundation Board, Lauper devoted a concert tour in 2005 to promoting the Foundation's message.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: She co-founded the True Colors tour for Human Rights throughout the United States and Canada in June 2007.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: One dollar from each ticket was earmarked for the Human Rights Campaign, which advocates equal rights for LGBT individuals.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: In 2008, Lauper started True Colors United (TCU) after learning that, while 10% of American youth identify themselves as LGBT, up to 40% of American homeless youths do so.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: The organization works to end youth homelessness, focusing on the experiences of LGBT youth.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: She set up the True Colors Residence in New York City for LGBT homeless youths.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: The 30-bed facility offers temporary shelter and job placement help.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: In April 2010, TCU launched the Give a Damn campaign, to help get straight people more involved in LGBT rights.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: In August 2008, she contributed an article titled "Hope" to The Huffington Post, encouraging Americans to vote for Barack Obama in the upcoming United States presidential election.
section: == Activism ==

sentences: Lauper performed at the 2008 Democratic National Convention.
section: == Activism ==
== Legacy ==

sentences: Legacy ==
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Lauper was described by AllMusic's Lindsay Planer as "an iconoclastic vocalist who revolutionized the role of women in rock and roll".
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Over her 40-year career, she influenced multiple recording artists including Katy Perry, Lady Gaga, Vanessa Paradis, Tegan and Sara, and Yelle.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Due to her success and influence Lauper has been inducted into both the Hollywood and Songwriters Hall of Fame.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Stephen Thomas Erlewine of Spotify said She's So Unusual and Lauper's distinctive idiosyncratic appearance "helped popularize the image of punk and new wave for America, making it an acceptable part of the pop landscape".
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Rolling Stone magazine stated that her debut was "arguably the first time explicitly punk-influenced elements were front-and-center on the pop landscape, both musically and via Lauper's Patrick Lucas-styled ensembles, dressing up the droll Reagan decade in feminist chutzpah."
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: The album ranked at No. 487 on Rolling Stone's list of 500 Greatest Albums of All Time in 2003.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: The album ranked at No. 41 on Rolling Stone's list of Women Who Rock: The 50 Greatest Albums of All Time in 2012.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Rolling Stone's review stated, "A wild and wonderful skyrocket of a voice...
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Lauper's extraordinary pipes connect with the right material, the results sound like the beginning of a whole new golden age."
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Thirty years after its release, Entertainment Weekly called it an "everlastingly saucy supersmash".
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Sheila Moeschen argued that "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" "embodied a different kind of feminine aesthetic that ran counter to the raw sensuality and edginess of her contemporaries like Madonna or veteran rockers Joan Jett and Pat Benatar", that introduced "a nation of women to a new kind of female role model, one that celebrated difference and encouraged playfulness in self-expression".
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: John Rockwell wrote that the song was "a giddily upbeat attestation to female pleasure that simultaneously made a feminist statement, fulfilled male fantasies and—especially in its often-played video version—evoked the warmth of family and friends".
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Its music video won the first-ever Best Female Video prize at the 1984 VMAs.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: It featured a multicultural cast of women with teased, sideways hair and neon eye shadow, singing alongside Lauper."Time
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: After Time" has been covered by over a hundred artists and was ranked at No. 22 on Rolling Stone's 100 Best Songs of the Past 25 Years and at No. 19 on VH1's 100 Greatest Songs of the 80s.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: "She Bop", the third single from She's So Unusual, is the first and only top ten song to directly mention a gay porn magazine.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: An ode to masturbation, it was included in the PMRC's "Filthy Fifteen" list that led to the parental advisory sticker appearing on recordings thought to be unsuitable for young listeners.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: In a retrospective, Rolling Stone ranked it the 36th best song of 1984, praising its unusual playfulness regarding sexuality.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: "True Colors" is a gay anthem, after which True Colors United, which advocates for runaway and homeless LGBT youth, is named.
section: == Legacy ==
